0780626966|5.0|Grimy hands, worktools, an old rag torn to shreds, a girl in a nightdress and.....a bleating lamb??? Cue an audience in 1984 going berserk. Welcome Freddy Krueger, we've been expecting you.<BR>Anyway you cut (or gut it if you prefer), A Nightmare on Elm Street is one of the most influential horror movies ever made. Wes Craven's nasty little shocker about evil personified weaves under the skin in an altogether far too realistic way, a feeling that is not entirely unpleasant. Eighties horror was basically piggy backed by the gleeful demon in the red and green sweater, look away Michael Myers and Jason Voorhees, back in the closet Chucky, stay in the shed Leatherface, sorry your trip from hell was wasted Pinhead. You guys are cool but you're simply not imaginative enough. Freddy would be ashamed of his stumbling slow witted contemporaries. Of course the original is by far and away the most impressive installment in the series, but what of the others? Freddy's Revenge suffered simply due to the fact that the film makers didn't have a clue where to take Freddy yet, lay responsibility in that Wes Craven was no longer involved, and therefore broke every rule estabilished in the previous film. It's only saving grace is the highly under rated performance by the startling Mark Patton. The Dream Warriors is quite simply stunning, the deaths are inventive, the characterisation and performances strong throughout and Freddy finally stepped from the shadows, eliciting screams and laughter in equal measure, a tradition picked up and embraced by the visually impressive Dream Master. The less said about The Dream Child the better, turning Freddy into a slapstick cartoon character, thereby destroying his menace and foreboding presence onscreen. And I swear to god, if I ever meet Rachael Talalay (director of the puerile Freddy's Dead), she'll truly understand what it's like to meet Freddy's glove. Ahem, sorry about that, just upsets me is all how someone so closely involved with the series from the get go can make such a Comedy Central impression of a Nightmare film. Craven came back to put the wrong things right in New Nightmare which he succeeded in doing with a cleverly scripted 'real life' drama, displaying once again his versatility, and rounding off the boxset in style. All in all, a wicked and (for the most part) enjoyable little jog around Elm Street is on offer for anyone wanting to check out the right way to off a teenager. One last thing of note, as Jason Vs Freddy nears production, please remember that Freddy is a disgusting and perverted child abuser and that is what makes him such a truly terrifying creation. Bring him back to something approaching his demeanor from Nightmare One rather than rehash his ill advised James Bond bad guy suave previous incarnations.<BR>Sweet dreams Miss Talalay.
B00006FXB6|3.0|There has been a lot of talk about Songs For the Deaf by QOTSA - a lot of big talk, a lot of hyperbolistic sensationalism. Many would tell you that SFTD song titles 'The Sky Is Fallin' and 'God Is In The Radio' are unintentionally prophetic and that finally, at long last, your musical revolution has arrived and that Dave Grohl is still its drummer.<br />Now before you pick up this disc expecting the second coming, Songs For the Deaf will not align the planets or even balance your checkbook. That said, it is likely to reunite you with a lost love.<br />With Songs For the Deaf, QOTSA have improved drastically from Y2K's Rated R. The same sense of vocal harmony exists with the guitars but, thanks in large part to the aforementioned Grohl, the band is much tighter. This is best exemplified by opening single, 'No One Knows'. On the track Grohl's snare jumps out the speaker and the band follows with a low end riff that make the song among the catchiest of the year. Queens of the Stone Age are a machine.<br />The songwriting is much improved as well. Josh Homme and Nick Olivari depended more on gimmickry on Rated R, but here every song succeeds being equally fresh and traditional and there is an enduring quality that reveals itself after the first several playings.<br />It is easy to understand how rock diehards might confuse this as revelutionary. It plays closely with their hopes with its compressed production values (similar to 70's radio) and tacky mock DJs ridiculing 'commercial music'. Songs For The Deaf is a very enjoyable rock record, and those have become more scarce of late. Let it reunite you with that lost love and do balance your checkbook by yourself.
B00005T5YK|5.0|Hotel California is arguably the best album of all time from the Eagles. Some might say that it is the greatest album of all time, period, though I would not go quite that far. Nevertheless, I will prize this release as my very first audio DVD, just as I have prized The Police's Ghost in the Machine as my very first CD, which I purchased back in late 1985.<br />The sound quality on the Hotel California DVD is quite superb. Through my DVD player, I played the CD version of the song Hotel California from the Eagles' second volume of greatest hits and compared it with the DVD version. It turns out that there is no comparison, whatsoever. The DVD audio is just simply a distant winner.<br />Special care was taken in the production. Included is a videotaped interview with Bill Szymczyk, who described in full detail the care that was taken in the mixing of the master tapes and how he wisely decided to call on the services of the most highly sought-after experts on both recording technology and sound quality.<br />If you ever take the time to listen, you will be delighted by the advanced resolution in the sound quality and how the vocals and instrumentations are simultaneously separated and reverberated throughout the six channels. In terms of awesome sound quality, Victim of Love never sounded so good. As a plus, if you prefer DTS 5.1 or if you opt for Dolby Digital, both options, where you can choose either one, are contained in this disc for your listening enjoyment.

B00006AW2O|5.0|12x5 is the first great Rolling Stones record. Their versions of \\"Time Is On My Side\\", originally done by the great Irma Thomas, and Bobby Womack's \\"It's All Over Now\\" have become Stones classics, while lesser known tracks like \\"Empty Heart\\", which has some ripping guitar riffs, \\"Confessin' The Blues\\" and \\"Good Times, Bad Times\\" stand right up next to them. The band pays tribute to Chess Records with the instrumental \\"2120 South Michigan Avenue\\". 12x5 solidified the foundation for their now almost 40 year career.

B00006AW2M|4.0|The much maligned Their Satanic Majesties Request is The Rolling Stones obvious response to The Beatles Sgt. Pepper's album. The band dived headfirst into the psychedelic sounds of 1967's Summer of Love and the album sounds like no other in their catalog. Despite the criticism and attempt to keep pace with the Beatles (including the original 3-D cover), the album contains some excellent songs. The album opens up strong with the overture &quot;Sing This All Together&quot; with it's horns and sound effects and then slides right into the grinding guitar of &quot;The Citadel&quot;. Bill Wyman's only lead vocal on a Stone's album is &quot;In Another Land&quot; and upon listening to it you can hear why it was his first and last. He has a tremendously thin voice and he makes Ringo Starr sound like Pavarotti. &quot;2000 Man&quot; is fast-paced and along with &quot;2000 Light Years From Home&quot; are the best songs on the album. The reprise of &quot;Sing This All Together&quot; is a major misstep and is a really bad song, but they pick up again with the flowery &quot;She's A Rainbow&quot;. This album has taken an undue amount of heat, but as the years have passed, it should be looked at for what it is, a solid foray into the psychedelic arena by one of the best bands of all-time.

B00005YXZH|5.0|I hardly ever write reviews, but I've been reading the comments here and decided to add mine. Fans of Wilco who enjoy their early alt-country sound shouldn't pick up this record, because that's not what you get. People who liked the more pop-oriented Summerteeth may not enjoy it, either, although there are echoes of that release on this one (the tracks \\"Kamera,\\" \\"Heavy Metal Drummer,\\" and \\"Pot Kettle Black,\\" for example). Wilco has definitely expanded on their earlier work on Yankee Hotel Foxtrot, marrying catchy pop melodies with experiments in noise and distortion. Judging from the other reviews here, it may not be enough experimentation for those listeners who want something really avant garde, and it's too much for people who want radio-friendly pop songs that don't require anything from the listener. However, if you don't fall into either of those categories, you may want to give YHF a chance. Repeated listens are a must to truly appreciate the sound that Wilco has created. They also give you a chance to think about Jeff Tweedy's often poetic lyrics, like these from \\"Jesus, Etc.\\": \\"tall buildings shake/ voices escape singing sad sad songs/ tuned to chords strung down your cheeks/ bitter melodies turning your orbit around.\\" If you're not sure YHF is for you, do what I did-borrow it and give it a listen. You may be glad you did.
B00006AW2G|5.0|Let It Bleed is the bluesiest of all the Stones' records and this probably has to do with the addition of former Bluesbreakers guitarist Mick Taylor to the band. He adds some fine slide and blues guitar work to the band. This album sounds like it could have been recorded in the Mississippi Delta. In fact &quot;Love In Vain&quot; is an old blues song that the band sings in a dirge-like fashion. &quot;Midnight Rambler&quot; sounds like something that Muddy Waters could have written. &quot;Let It Bleed&quot; contains just a simple guitar and drum backing, but is a great song. &quot;You Got The Silver&quot; has Keith singing lead and it is some of his best vocal work ever. &quot;Country Honk&quot; is a country reworking of their number one hit rocker &quot;Honky Tonk Woman&quot;. There are some hard rockers on the album including the opening track &quot;Gimme Shelter&quot; and the scorching &quot;Live with Me&quot;. &quot;Monkey Man&quot; is one the most underappreciated songs in the Stones catalog. Martin Scorcese used it brilliantly in the film &quot;Goodfellas&quot; and it contains some classic screeching by Jagger. Of course the most played track on the album is the last one, &quot;You Can't Always Get What You Want&quot;. It's the Stones slap of reality to the hippie's love &amp; peace movement and a foreshadowing of the violence that would pierce the country, including their own Altamont show.  Let It Bleed very well could be the band's finest work and it is one of the best albums in the history of rock.

B00006AW2E|5.0|Out Of Our Heads contains the strongest original material from the band's first few albums released between 1963-1965. The UK version does not contain the classic &quot;(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction&quot; or &quot;Play With Fire&quot;.  But this version has a harder, bluesy edge with a ripping &quot;Hitch Hike&quot; and a sultry &quot;Hearts Of Stone&quot;. Heads marks a major leap by the Jagger-Richards songwriting team and the band was really starting the gel.

B00006AW2J|5.0|Beggars Banquet was the last album released by the original Stones lineup, although Brian Jones is reported to have barely played on it. It was a strong comeback by the band, who in trying to compete with the Beatles and fit in with the Psychadelic scene, had released the terribly misguided Their Satantic Majesties Request. Beggars strips away all the musically gimmickry and provides the listener with bare-bones rock. \\"Sympathy For The Devil\\" has taken on a life of its own and has become the band's manifesto. \\"No Expectations\\", \\"Dear Doctor\\", \\"Prodical Son\\" & \\"Factory Girl\\" find the band exploring country music themes for the first time. With their sexual themes, \\"Parachute Woman\\" & \\"Stray Cat Blues\\" put the band in familiar territory. The album closes with their anthem for the little man, the earnest \\"Salt Of The Earth\\". Beggars Banquet closes one era of the band while opening up a new one. They say goodbye to Brian Jones and start a music path that would produce some of the greatest albums ever recorded in musical history
B00005QIPH|3.0|A decent start from a decent band- not the saviors of rock or whatever, but not as horrible as some would say. You can't control what the media machine churns out, so just focus on the music, not on the fact that MTV/Rolling Stone are crediting bands like this one (as well as Hives/Vines) as the future of rock based on the strengths of debut singles. The songs here are pretty catchy in a breezy/gritty style. Not THE catchiest band around, though, and not the most rockin' either. It's too bad that they're overshadowing true masters of the game like Guided By Voices and Spoon, but that's not their fault I guess. Like I said, good enough, but won't crack my top 10 for the year by a long stretch...

The band started to step away from the heavy R&B sounds of their earlier albums. B00006AW2F|4.0|Metamorphosis was originally released in 1975 , but never found its way onto a compact disk.  The album finally makes its digital debut.  The genesis of the album was to thwart bootlegs of the rare and unreleashed music the band had made.  Although they are Stones songs, practically none of the songs are full band efforts.  Many of the songs like &quot;Out Of Time&quot; were set up as blueprints for other artists to follow as the Mick Jagger and Keith Richards were farming out their surplus material.  Despite this, the album is an enjoyable affair and long overdue for Stones fans.

0451457994|5.0|Do you like thrilling expeditions to other worlds?  How about mysterious, cryptic occurences?  If so, then you'll most likely love this awe-inspiring science fiction novel!  The book starts out with an intriguing few chapters several million years ago, when apes still roamed the earth, creating a sort of background upon which many of the sometimes incomprehensible shadows of the story are thrown.  The tale suddenly changes to what when it was written {1969} would be the future: 2001, when the universe has become a prime target for research and daring astronauts.  Among these is Dr. Heywood Floyd, who embarks on a secretive mission to Earth's Moon in order to study a peculiar monolith recently dug up that is emitting strange radio waves towards Saturn.  Eighteen years later, David Bowman and Frank Poole journey into space to check out Saturn onboard the advanced craft Discovery, which is run by the talking, terrifically, and dangerously, intelligent HAL 9000 computer.  However, what the duo does not realize, which HAL guiltily does, is that the odyssey is really a quest for extraterrestrial life, hinted at by the Moon's compelling monolith, but all will not go as planned.  When a horrible tragedy occurs, brought on by HAL losing all control of his mechanical emotions, and therefore, his sanity, only David Bowman is left to strategically continue on with the odyssey alone.  Of course, his very survival lies in the hands of the universe, and he finds himself captured by an unrecognizable force which drags Dave into perhaps one of the greatest enigmas of all time...and then makes him a chilling part of it.<br />I must admit that when I finished Arthur C. Clarke's spellbinding novel, I was incredibly confused and a little shaken by the note it leaves off on, but the ingenious plot became clearer after some pondering.  The hooking suspense and power of Clarke's masterful language alone make the book a great read, besides the unforgettable adventures to beautiful wonders in the universe and extremely thought-out, interrelated plot twists.  Whether because of its astronomical appeal or undeniable brilliancy, this is one odyssey which will always remain, in my mind, an absolutely exhilarating tribute to the cosmos and the entire human race itself.  The movie may be fairly enjoyable, but the actual book is a quintessential part of anyone's and everyone's bookshelf.
B00005QIPH|3.0|The Strokes seem to have achieved this weird status with Is This It of being the saviors of rock, and the group that will pull this world out of its Britney-intensive dung heap and take us to a wonderful era of music being something more than a business and the producer becoming a thing of the past... or something. The fact is, The Strokes were hyped as the saviors of rock, and their producers decided to market them as revolutionary. I'm sorry I had to say that, but this album has gained so much hype that any review of it has to address the hype.<br />Now, there is actually music on this CD, so let's talk about that too. This album has some shockingly catchy songs on it. &quot;Someday&quot; was stuck in my head for about a week straight, and, after hearing &quot;Hard To Explain&quot;, I had to buy the album to make the song go away. Don't expect anything deep coming into this album. This are pretty much good pop songs.<br />Bottom line: It's over-hyped, fun, catchy, and just generally listenable. Out of Our Heads was the fifth remaster I purchased and I was completely disappointed.  I remembered very much enjoying the record as a teen.  It is a bit of a hodge podge, singles pieced together to form an album.  The performances are still good for the most part, there are some all time classics like Satisfaction and one or two lost classics like Spider and the Fly; a couple of tracks don't hit the mark at all. The sound on the remaster is not only not improved from the earlier it is worse.  I promptly returned it for Aftermath which is a joy and an enormous sonic improvement. Out of our Heads, three stars, hasn't aged well, overrated in retropect, and a lousy remastering job.  Get Beggar's Banquet. Next up NOW and Let it Bleed.

0767817710|4.0|It took me many years to finally decide to watch The Quick and the Dead. It didn't look that interesting, and I thought had the potential to be a bad film. But Sam Raimi did direct it, so I knew there was potential for it to be good. And it is. Raimi is the man who directed the Evil Dead series, Spider-Man, Darkman, and The Gift, and helped to bring us Xena and Brisco County. So this western has the Raimi flair. It's a straightforward story of redemption and revenge, told with Raimi's stylistic flair. Leonardo DiCaprio and Russell Crowe give good performances, and Gene Hackman does a great job as the main baddie (no surprise there). Even Sharon Stone does a good job of portraying Ellen with the right amount of anger, fear, and uncertainty. But Stone's performance isn't quite as convincing as the other actors'. There's something missing from her performance. But it is a solid movie. The dvd contains no extras.

0553381709|5.0|Monumental power struggles with numerous players, all with their own agendas. The people who populate the pages of Martin's books are as varied as the stones in a stream bed. Some arrogant and mean spirited, they spit, curse, ... and murder their way towards their goals, while some just try to survive after their worlds crumble. These are books where the \\"good\\" characters often make bad decisions and the \\"bad\\" characters are occasional allies. It keeps you guessing what will happen next and who will live to tell about it. It is brilliant and complex - without being tangled. <br />Bravo - George - for being a masterful storyteller who knows how to use both unexpected strengths and weaknesses to make a character \\"human\\" and most of all, for not sacrificing reality to bend to the romantics need for fluff and last minute miracles. Thank you for every character who vomits at the stench of death or ... himself as the cold draws closer. It makes the horror more palpable and the suspense of what will happen next, pure torture.

B000069KE0|5.0|&quot;Chicago II&quot; takes the momentum created by their first album, &quot;Chicago Transit Authority&quot; and raises their crisp, clear &quot;sound&quot; to a higher level.  The album flows naturally from one song into the next.  The listener will get a better feel for &quot;stand-alone&quot; singles like &quot;Make Me Smile&quot;, &quot;Colour My World&quot; and &quot;24 or 6 to 4&quot; when they listen to them in the sequence in which they were recorded.<br />The six song set called Ballet For a Girls in Buchannon is reason alone to get this album. New fans will gain immediate respect for one of the 70's pioneer &quot;brass-oriented&quot; groups.  Either way, no one loses with this great album!  Enjoy!
B000063S6Z|3.0|When Play was released in 1999, it was basically dead to the charts. Moby's music, to most people, must have seemed like a strange cacophony of samples and instruments and/or repetitivie musical patterns. Nonetheless, Moby received a plethora of critical accolade for the cd--as well as his other works--and also a small, but loyal, underground following. I purchased Play before it had been given on a silver platter to numerous companies and before Gwen Stafani leant her vocals to &quot;South Side.&quot; I purchased it on the strength of songs such as &quot;Porcelain,&quot; &quot;Natural Blues,&quot; and &quot;Body Rock&quot; and I think the reason is simple: diversity. Play is probably one of the more diverse electronica albums I own and it is because of this diversity that 18 seems so lackluster.<br />I will admit that I decided to get 18 on an irrational proclivity where if I have one stellar cd from an artist then I will immediately purchase the following ones. Because of this large confirmation bias I will sometimes buy cd's that, though not bad, do not meet my expectations. 18 is an anomaly because it seems to fit better as a *prequel* to Play than a follow-up. The mechanics are relatively the same but the difference on 18 is that songs seem to form a tessellated work which gets more dull with every listen. From the boring &quot;We are All Made of Stars&quot; to the up-beat &quot;Extreme Ways,&quot; nothing really seems to project itself as unique on 18. At certain points I wonder if Moby merely used the same samples. The crucial difference is that Play fashioned itself as a stunning, diverse project since the first three singles placed different emphasis on musical structure (&quot;Body Rock&quot; sounded more trance than the ambient &quot;Porcelain&quot;). 18 comes with few distinctions (&quot;Jam for The Ladies&quot; and &quot;Extreme Ways&quot; being the only two) and failed attempts to break new musical territory (the Zero 7-inspired &quot;Fireworks&quot;).<br />This dour review, however, should not seem that way if one has never heard Play. I recommend this cd to those who want an introduction to Moby's style since 18 sounds like sort of the last artistic sputter before the engine got going on Play. It isn't a bad cd but it simply does not compare to Play in any manner.<br />If you have Play, there is no need to get 18.<br />If do not have Play, then it is a good idea to get 18.<br />This dour review, however, should not seem that way if one has never heard Play. I recommend this cd to those who want an introduction to Moby's style since 18 sounds like sort of the last artistic sputter before the engine got going on Play. It isn't a bad cd but it simply does not compare to Play in any manner.<br />If you have Play, there is no need to get 18.<BR>If do not have Play, then it is a good idea to get 18.
B000001ESN|4.0|Okay, I'm back to the Rush reviews. PERMANENT WAVES (1980) marked the beginning of Rush's 'middle period', i.e. they were still a Heavy Metal band, albeit a progressive one, but their songs began to get a bit shorter and more radio-friendly at this point. This would be a bad thing for most bands; however with Rush, it just made their sound more accessible while still packing a powerful lyrical punch, courtesy of drumming and songwriting genius Neil Peart, the band's resident Ayn Rand. It also gained Rush tremendous popularity, while not 'selling out'. The swirling guitar/keyboard music also packs a wallop in its own way; it's not as loud or heavy as it had been in the band's early days, but is no less heartfelt. Rush's signature time-changes are on full display on every song on this album, and if anything, Rush's music became even more complex-just more compact.<br />And what a compact recording PERMANENT WAVES is: containing only six songs and stretching only 35 minutes, this album is short even by Rush standards. But every song is significant, magical and has something to say. \\"Spirit of Radio\\" is the opening track and, of course, the one that people know best from this album. Although it may have eventually suffered a little from too much FM-radio overplay, one cannot deny the timelessness of its message. In fact, its thesis of corporate erosion of the integrity of modern music is perhaps even more relevant today than it was at the dawn of the 1980's, what with the increased proliferation of manufactured entertainers such as Billy Ray Cyrus, the Backstreet Boys, 'Nsync, O-Town, Eden's Crush, etc etc. \\"Freewill\\" has a strongly individualistic message to which most people can relate, as it deals with the choice of how to live one's life and the methods by which one arrives at that choice. Musically, it pulls out all the stops: It contains one of the greatest Alex Lifeson guitar solos of all time, and I love the way it incorporates Rush's earlier style by having Geddy Lee screaming the bridge, with echo and reverb aplenty. Interestingly enough, this would be the very last time we would hear Geddy's early-Rush-style scream (previously heard to great effect on RUSH, FLY BY NIGHT, CARESS OF STEEL, 2112, AND A FAREWELL TO KINGS), as his voice was already mellowing out considerably, and would mellow out even more as time went by.<br />In continuation, we get \\"Jacob's Ladder,\\" one of two long songs on the CD, and definitely one to relax to while listening. Its beautiful, poetic lyrics are spare, and its music spans the spectrum from soft to hard and then soft again. Geddy Lee's keyboard abilities are in sharp focus here, as well as Neil Peart's strangely off-kilter, syncopated drumming (which is his trademark, of course). \\"Entre Nous\\" (\\"Between Us\\") deals poetically with the concept of interpersonal relationships, \\"Different Strings\\" is the one Lee-penned track on here; an abstract love song of sorts, it shows how much he had really grown as a lyricist from his \\"Take A Friend\\" days. Finally, the closer \\"Natural Science\\" is the one multi-part suite on PERMANENT WAVES; clocking in at over nine minutes, it marks a bit of a return to the epic style displayed on 2112, A FAREWELL TO KINGS, and HEMISPHERES. Its weird space-age sound and vocal effects in fact remind me very much of AFTK's \\"Cygnus X-1.\\" Similarly, it does merit some repeated listenings in order to 'get into it'.<br />PERMANENT WAVES marked the beginning of a new direction for Rush. Indeed, with this album, the stage was set for an all-time masterpiece...which will be discussed later. All in all, this CD is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
B00005S8FC|3.0|There is nothing shocking about this album. There is nothing new about tango-fusion, which exists since the 70s, if not earlier.<br />I don't know what were the intentions of the musicians who made this album and frankly I don't care. The bottom line is that this makes good background music without going much further. The danger of making trance music is monotony and unfortunately ALL the tracks on this album do fall into it. However they still manage to keep our interest for the first 2 or 3 minutes of each track. After that, we just don't really listen anymore, but at least it doesn't get annoying to the point that we have to stop the CD player.<br />I'm afraid this music will fade into oblivion because its monotony. Or maybe not. There is a market for background music after all, and this stylish CD is quite good within that category.

0688170528|5.0|The Hartes and the Golds have been best friends for years.  They've shared everything: pregnancy, Chinese food, and a strong love for their children.  So, it comes as a surprise to no one when their son and daughter, Chris and Emily, fall in love and start dating at age 13.  <br />What does come as a surprise is being called to the hospital late one night.  Emily is dead of a gunshot wound, and Chris is badly injured. He says it was a suicide pact.  The authorities, however, aren't so sure, and soon accuse Chris of Emily's murder.<br />The tension throughout this book, as to what really happened to Emily, is palpable.  Until the very end, I found myself believing BOTH stories depending on who was telling the tale.  The prison and courtroom scenes were well-researched and compelling, and the relationship between Chris and Emily's parents make a wonderful sub-plot. <br />Most of all, this book made me think a great deal about what love can, and cannot, make us do for other people and for ourselves.  I was terribly impressed with this book by Picoult, and look forward to reading more of her work.

0060930349|5.0|First, to almost everyone who has posted something, contray to what most high school history teachers &quot;teach&quot;, history is not about facts and dates. The study of history is about how people interpret facts to develop opinions of the past. All good historians write with the goal of developing an opinion of history and supporting it with facts. For a person to dismiss a piece of historical writing as biased or subjective merely shows that person's ignorance and closed-mindedness. Anyone desiring to expand their historical understanding should seek out as many different historical viewpoints as possible. The diffenece between a good historian and a poor historian is that the good historian's thesis is clear from the first paragraph, giving the intelligent reader an insight into the writer's &quot;bias,&quot; while a poor historian hides behind the veil of &quot;objective&quot; history displayed in texts such as high school textbooks, the most inaccurate and irresponsible historical writing one can find.<br />Paul Johnson's book is an example of the former. It is a refreshingly optimistic approach to US history, something the history profession had been lacking since the 1960s. It is very enjoyable and insightful.<br />So what if his take on American history does not fit with the standard left-wing intellectual historical interpretations that are often passed for &quot;fact.&quot;  The whole idea of &quot;left-wing&quot; and &quot;right-wing&quot; is meanless anyway. I don't always agree with Johnson (Nixon for example), though sometimes I do (FDR); but it is refreshing to read something a little different than the standard &quot;objective&quot; drivel. Differing opinions are one of the many things that made the USA a great country. And it is a great country. If it wasn't, people would not have been risking everything to come here in the 1620s! <br />Johnson looks at the United States a work in progress, still struggling to create the society dreamed of in theDeclaration of Independence. Unlike so many historians who dwell on the evils of the past, Johnson sees the past as a sign that the United States is heading in the right direction and getting better all of the time. And I agree.

0385503954|5.0|It has been several months since I finished reading Ian McEwan's ATONEMENT and several weeks since I finished re-reading it.  It actually took me this long to collect my thoughts about this astounding achievement.  ATONEMENT is quite simply one of the most moving, beautifully written contemporary novels I have ever read.  As opposed to the last McEwan novel I read, AMSTERDAM, which was a tour de force of black, comic word play, ATONEMENT is a novel of character in which true, vivid but bleak emotions are always in play.  <br />The book is divided into three distinct sections:  the first deals with a British family at their great home, much like E.M. Forster might have written; the second part which takes place several years later during World War 2 takes us to France and part three is in 1999 and we are returned to the family home at a birthday party for one of the three leading characters, a celebrated novelist, who, during her childhood committed a crime so cruel that she has spent her entire life looking for some sort of atonement.<br />The depiction of the horrors of war in the second part of this novel is the most shattering I've ever read mainly because of McEwan's varied and specific details dealing with the lives of several soldiers retreating after a major defeat.  One of these soldiers has been wrongly imprisoned for the crime in part one.  Every other character is new to the reader, but fully and beautifully developed.  Every section, every single page is so filled with life, both good and bad, romantic and villainous, nostalgic and adventure-laden that one cannot help but read and be thrilled at McEwan's control and mastery.  <br />This is absolutely a book to treasure.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

B000002L7J|4.0|Although The Queen Is Dead is almost universally cited as being the best album from The Smiths, Meat Is Murder, while perhaps not as polished and refined - being a bit more raw and free-form - I find to be, in most respects, superior. On The Queen Is Dead, The Smiths, in particular with regards to their music, managed to craft finely-wrought pop songs (Cemetery Gates, The Boy With The Thorn In His Side); on this album, however, the songs are much more raw and rocking, while also exhibiting a huge jump in scope from their debut album. On that album, the music was quite simplistic and seemed to function mainly as background noise for the vocals. Meat Is Murder is quite different. As is evident from the driving intro of the very first song, The Headmaster Ritual, as well as on others (Rusholme Ruffians, How Soon Is Now), Johnny Marr constructed a dense web of guitars, with some great backing from one of rock's most criminally underrated bassists, Andy Rourke. The arrangements even veer toward the epic on such keyboard-laden tracks as the closing title song. Also, lyrically, this album is a major advance from the debut. Morrissey's lyrics here exhibited much of the teen angst that would come to define him and The Smiths for many people, particularly on The Queen Is Dead and on many of their singles. Also, whereas the first album contained some social commentary (Suffer Little Children), it is in quite full force here, as we have songs dealing with: corporal punishment and education (The Headmaster Ritual); domestic punishment and child abuse (Barbarism Begins At Home); and, in a blatantly over-the-top song that many, including myself, dub as a mistake, the title track (its name leaves little doubt as to the content.) Last but not least, one cannot write a legitimate review of this album without mentioning How Soon Is Now?, a track, with its throbbing melody and utterly hopeless lyrics, may well be the best The Smiths ever recorded. An essential disc for fans of the band.
B00005QFE5|5.0|This is an incredible moving film.  Given the limited dialogs in this film, the director managed to convey the leading character's emotions. <br />I highly recommend this DVD.  I watched it for a second time and cried just as much...
B00003CXC6|5.0|Throughout the film you will be amazed at how far ahead of it's time it's film making experience was.  The extra material on this dvd fills you in on that. It's almost as if it set the new standards of film-making and furthered the process of film-watching itself.  While the film is decidely Japanese, it allows you to experience the story from several seperate views (including the views of the camera itself)- this is classic film-making at it's zenith. The characters also play a vital role in the dynamics of the film (and audience perspectives) by representing all aspects of society itself.  It also underlines the fact of &quot;what is truth?&quot; and &quot;who is right?&quot; in modern society.  Without overstating the facts, it draws you in to understand the characters themselves.  It's ending is also a desperate attempt for truth in the individual and hope in man accepting his own confused existance.  And so the setting of a court case is most fitting and its dynamics allow you to see all of it's seperate parts (including the jury and witnesses and audience within the court room).  It's almost as if your watching a play about a play.  The camera work is also the second director in the movie.  This movie is a must for any serious film-watcher.
014118213X|5.0|I have read Howard's End two or three times and listened to it once on tape and it remains one of my favorite novels. Many people were introduced to it by the film, which, good though it was, does not begin to capture the subtle wisdom Forster put into this book. Howard's End can be seen as a quaint period piece about British culture in the early Twentieth Century. On another level, however, it's a brilliant exploration of the human soul. In the Schlegels and the Wilcoxes, Forster has created the perfect embodiment of the eternal conflict between reason and passion. These two families, destined to be united by the marriage of Margaret Schlegel to Henry Wilcox, represent two seemingly irreconcilable aspects of humanity. The Schlegels are artistic, intellectual and impractical; the Wilcoxes materialistic and unapologetically bourgeois. Margaret and Henry have their differences, but it is their relatives who display the more extreme family traits. Margaret's sister Helen is a classic bohemian; Henry's son Charles is a humorless and intolerant banker. As the novel unfolds, the two families are forced to confront each other and decide whether to ultimately part company or compromise. What is most impressive to me about the novel is the naturalness and grace with which the story unfolds. When an author uses characters to embody universal qualities, it is quite a challenge to make the people and story real and not merely symbols. Howard's End succeeds brilliantly as both a thoroughly engaging novel and a rather profound metaphysical inquiry.

B00004WGAI|3.0|It almost ruined the book for me. <br />Yes, I know it's the most complete, authentic adaptation of the story, and I appreciate that. I hate the way Hollywood versions have Jane returning to Gateshead instead of Moor House, cut Diana and Mary out the story, etc. They also tried for a set closer to the Thornfield described in the book, rather than the overdone gothic castle set used in Hollywood versions, and I liked that as well.<br />However, the problem for me was with Dalton and Zelah Clarke. Separately they each had their strong points, but together they just didn't make &quot;Jane and Rochester.&quot;<br />I think my biggest problem was Dalton. I'm not a huge fan, to begin with. And he's far too handsome for Rochester, though I could forgive that for an actor who really fit the part. <br />He got some things right: he knows how to play an English gentleman; he captured Rochester's sardonic edge and  worldliness. However, I never felt Dalton quite connected with the character. Or perhaps a multi-layered portrayal was beyond him. <br />For the record, I have never seen Rochester as a ranter and growler. (Dalton, to his credit, didn't do much of that.) Yes, he can be dangerous, but I don't see that as his usual style. He is intelligent, with a vivid, almost poetic imagination. The actor who plays him should be able to convey that. Should, in fact, be the kind of actor who knows his way around a line of Shakespeare. One of the Fiennes brothers, let's say. <br />Dalton just doesn't have that, and that ruined many of his scenes for me. It ruined the basis for his connection with Jane. Both are intense, imaginative people. Take the climactic scene where they declare their love: It should be passionate, it should be charged. In this movie, it's so low key I was almost bored. Rather than ranting, Mr.Dalton erred to the other extreme.<br />Now when I think of those scenes in the book, I hear again how they were done in the movie, almost spoiling how I have imagined it. Ugh!<br />Another problem is the matching of the handsome, charismatic Dalton with an ordinary looking Jane. This doesn't generate believable chemistry. Maybe if they had connected intellectually, it would have worked better.<br />Ms. Clarke does have the intelligence, and she has the strength Jane should have, though she didn't make a particularly memorable Jane, and Jane needs a kind of charisma, too.<br />And Rochester, of course, is not supposed to be handsome. My advice: rent before you buy.
B00005YU1O|1.0|...<br />The first 10 minutes of the DVD contain some good \\"rotoscope\\" style animation -- at once intriguing and engaging.  And then the seasickness kicks in.  Perhaps using the queasiness engendered by the Blair Witch Project as a model, some of the animators seemed determined to conceal their attempts at art under a panopoly of discordant visual stimuli.  Who knows whether their attempts at art was successful?  <br />It is unviewable.<br />Like the \\"computer newbie\\" who's discovered different fonts, effects, and colors in a word-processing package, and seems to have sworn out a vendetta on white space, several of the animators use the Macintosh-hosted animation application to make their own work unwatchable.  Not content with the camera movement that the hand-held digital video backdrop provides, several of the animators place 'their' segment's background on multiple layers, each of which has been configured to rock back and forth -- out-of-synch with the others.  This completely unnatural effect will give you an eyeache, at the very least.  Persevere at your own peril.  You will be probably be rewarded with a splitting headache, and no comprehension of the animator's message, if you try to bear it out (as I must ruefully admit to having tried to do).<br />The animation application itself, the subject of a very good documentary -- shot with a tripod-mounted camera -- is very rich in functionality and has been developed to be useful for a broad range of users' talent-levels.  So what ...  I can only wish several of the animators had been forced to take lessons.  The ease of use of a camera, the interface of the application used for F/X in the Jurrasic Park movies, the difficulties trapping colors in blue-screen effects, and other technical issues should be concealed from the viewer.  <br />The producers of this film forgot this critical element.<br /><<NOTE TO ASPIRING FILMMAKERS:  Just because something can be done with an application, and just because someone else hasn't done that thing in the past with an application, doesn't make everything done with an application necessarily good.>>  <br /><<COROLLARY ONE TO NOTE:  Just because something is unwatchable, doesn't make it art.>>  <br /><<COROLLARY TWO TO NOTE:  Even if your work is art, wrapping it in sloppy application window-dressing will make your art indistinguishable from garbage.>><br />Don't waste your money on this one!!<br />...Please, please, don't waste your money on this one!

6305308659|4.0|Let's start with the major flaw in this movie, just to get it over with.  Whoever had the bright idea of attempting to correlate the premise of this film with the treatment of blacks in 50's and 60's America got it wrong.  It just doesn't fit, and detracts from what is otherwise an artistic and inspired dance on an interesting idea.  Thankfully, they don't push the analogy too far, so, in the end, in only mildly spoils the film.<br />But, let's get to the good stuff.  The central idea is that life in a 50's sitcom isn't very fulfilling for the people involved--only they don't know it yet.  Indeed, the characters in Pleasantville, a television series that never was, but could have been, live in blissful ignorance.  Ignorance of what, however?  You see, to this day, there are people who actually continue to believe that blissful ignorance is as good as bliss, and that it's okay to be happily unaware of a number of things that some of us believe might actually be the key to happiness--creativity, passion, curiousity, and raw emotion.  For the characters in Pleasantville, there are no surprises.  Dinner will always be waiting at six.  The counters will always get set with forks and knives before the french fries are cooked.<br />In other words, Pleasantville presents the idealized comfort of a world where everything has a place, and where everything is always in its place.  False comfort, in other words, and one which we sometimes dream about when facing the uncertainties, rejection, alienation, and anomie that sometimes comes along with being an ordinary human being with no idea of what lies beyond the next door, or whether that cute girl or guy might actually give us the time of day --or be a drug addict with a penchant for animal cruelty. (After all, it is that kind of world we live in--but don't worry about this movie treading such uncomfortable terrain. The movie doesn't need to go that far for us to get the picture.)<br />In many respects, this is a Garden of Eden allegory.  There's even a scene where Tobey Maguire's character gets fed the veritable apple--although I didn't think it was right that he should be doing the eating.  It seemed an unnecessary bit of sloppiness, or an unnecessary juxtaposition.  If any one is the serpent here, it's Tobey and his sister, played with relish, finesse, and flair by Reece Witherspoon.  Witherspoon is one of those actresses who, no matter what you think on first glimpse, has the ability to transform into a beautiful woman.  Frankly, there simply is a lot going on under her skin, and that, I think, has much to do with it.<br />So, the movie asks, what might happen if the serenity of Pleasantville were disturbed by a little of our reality?  And, likewise, what might a shallow, slutty girl of our world learn from a bit of Pleasantville?  It answers those questions entertainingly and lightly, but still with a bit of depth that is more than one comes to expect from mainstream movies.  Certainly, this movie won't shake your world, but it may make you pause to think about what is meaningful, and what isn't, while entertaining you with cleverness and visual beauty.<br />The movie could have--and maybe should have--gotten a bit more gritty.  The color brought to Pleasantville could have brought more pain, but no matter.  It works and is, in the end, a very pleasant diversion.f Eden allegory.  There's even a scene where Tobey Maguire's character gets fed the veritable apple--although I didn't think it was right that he should be doing the eating.  It seemed an unnecessary bit of sloppiness, or an unnecessary juxtaposition.   If any one is the serpent here, it's Tobey and his sister, played with relish, finesse, and flair by Reece Witherspoon.  Witherspoon is one of those actresses who, no matter what you think on first glimpse, has the ability to transform into a beautiful woman.   Frankly, there simply is a lot going on under her skin, and that, I think, has much to do with it.  <br />So, the movie asks, what might happen if the serenity of Pleasantville were disturbed by a little of our reality?  And, likewise, what might a shallow, slutty girl of our world learn from a bit of Pleasantville?  It answers those questions entertainingly and lightly, but still with a bit of depth that is more than one comes to expect from mainstream movies.  Certainly, this movie won't shake your world, but it may make you pause to think about what is meaningful, and what isn't, while entertaining you with cleverness and visual beauty.  <br />The movie could have--and maybe should have--gotten a bit more gritty.  The color brought to Pleasantville could have brought more pain, but no matter.  It works and is, in the end, a very pleasant diversion.

6305308659|5.0|Count me as one Christian (Episcopalian) who loved the movie. <br />I would rate this up there with the \\"Last Temptation of Christ\\" in its theological exploration. <br />...<br />The townsfolk of Pleasantville live seemingly idyllic lives that are without pain, suffering, crime or any other kind of evil. Everything happens the way it is supposed to and their is no world beyond their town. But they also are emotionally stunted, superficial and unable to think for themselves. They follow a script and have no free will or ability to think for themselves. They have not been exposed to anything beyond their myopic existences. <br />The God character (played by Don Knotts) transports Bud and and Peggy Sue (serpent figure??) into this world. They begin introducing those around them to both good, evil and knowledge (art and literature). The townspeople learn to make moral choices and learn the realities of real joy and real pain and evil.<br />As this occurs, their eyes are opened, they learn free will they and are transformed from (literally and metaphorically) black-and-white to colour. As this occurs, the physical world around them changes. The basketball players don't always make their shots. The weather isn't always perfect. Trees catch on fire. But creation becomes coloured as well. Perhaps the imperfection of creation is necessary for those within it to be truly human.<br />It's a brilliant exploration of the concepts that Genesis 1 introduces. Was the fall and free will and the potential for evil necessary for us to gain our full humanity? That is a question I've wondered for a while.<br />Those Christians who call this anti-values or anti-Christian don't seem to have the gift of subtlety. Peggy Sue doesn't turn colour until she TURNS DOWN the offer to have sex with Skip and spends the night studying and learning to think outside her particular box. Not everyone at Lover's Lane is colour, but those who have emotional connections with their spouses do.<br />...P>ButI do recommend this movie for those people of any faith who like to wrestle with theological and moral concepts. It might even be a good movie to use as a start for theological discussion for Jewish, Unitarian and Christian small groups. If you like to think and ponder, watch this.

B00005QZWI|5.0|There is no better recommendation I can give than that. I knew the plot before going in, yet Fellowship of the Ring kept me on the edge of my seat. Was it because of the special effects? No, though they were superb. Or the monsters, like the huge cave troll that attacks the Fellowship in Balin's tomb, or better yet, the immense balrog, a fiery monster as colossal as a small skyscraper? No. It is because of the almost hopeless and insane mission the free peoples undertake to defeat their Enemy. <br />As powerful as the elves and their human allies were, their might paled when measured against the overwhelming magic of Sauron, the Lord of the Rings. His armies were powerful and numerous beyond belief, yet Frodo, Gandalf, and the rest of the Fellowship undertook an almost hopeless task- to take the One Ring into Mordor and fling it into the fires of Mount Doom, the only way they had to destroy the ring. Why? Using the Ring themselves would only set up another Dark Lord, thus propagating the insidious evil of a blackened and brooding god. (Who? His name is Morgoth, just in case you're wondering. Read Tolkien's Silmarillion to find out more!) The Ring HAD to be destroyed, not used... and the only way to get to Mount Doom was a long and incredibly dangerous trek through dozens and dozens of miles of enemy territory. Frodo, the innocent nephew of Bilbo Baggins, was the being chosen to carry through this task. The world was against him and his fellow warriors... yet they follow through with their mission. Imagine this- the only way to defeat the armies of Hitler was for three virtually unarmed men to walk through Germany, straight into the heart of his power- and destroy the magic talisman that kept him alive and empowered his armies. Hopeless? Yes. But it had to be done.<br />Howard Shore's music captures the ebullient spirit of the hobbits, the steadfast bravery of Boromir and Aragorn, and the hideously dangerous power and malice of Sauron, the Dark Lord, creator of the One Ring, whose immense magic would enable him to rule the world. And once he regained his treasure, taken from him by Isildur, thousands of years before, Sauron would rule for thousands of years. Very likely, tens of thousands, all the while mashing freedom and justice into paste under his iron fist and implacable evil. Shore's music for Sauron is a constant thread running throughout this intense movie. It's Satanic in its evil and magnificent in its awesome power. The music demands a great deal from the listener- who or what can stand against this evil? <br />The bravery, the love, the sheer humanity of the united peoples are what stand steadfast against the Satanic power of Sauron. Howard Shore's score brings that bravery into the light again and again, thus re-affirming the hopes of the free peoples. When Boromir tries to take the Ring by force, we feel Frodo's fear of his onetime human ally... yet, Boromir redeems himself, giving his life in fierce combat with Saruman's Uruk Hai, the abominable crosses between men and orcs Saruman, the supposed ally of the free peoples, made by means of a rotten and fell magic. What power there is in this scene! And Howard Shore's music sears it into the soul. This is followed by Enya's haunting May It Be, which moves me to tears every time I listen to it. As some of the other reviewers noted, this is not a score to relax by, though it does have its lighter moments. It is, however, a score which delves deeply into the spirit of humanity, even in non-human creatures (Hobbits, Dwarves, Elves, and Ents. These last should be in The Two Towers and The Return of the King.) and the timeless evil of tyrannical monsters, like Saruman and Sauron. The sound is excellent, just in case you have been living on Mars and haven't seen the movie.

B00000J7J7|2.0|Brad Mehldau has rejected comparisons between himself and Bill Evans, going so far as to say that he himself is not particularly fond of Evans' playing.  In listening to Mr. Mehldau, it becomes clear that this is so: the harmonic structure he employs in his chordal playing and development is rather stark and modal.  Where Evans and other pianists employ voicings and inventive use of the left hand, Mehldau is not only predictable but morose and stuck in minor scales completely absent of any interesting key modulation.  This album sounds like a mediocre new age musician trying desparately to play jazz. Another disappointing feature of this ablum is what appears to be an attempt to bring certain classical features to the mix.  At times, it seems as if he wants to sound like Chopin's Nocturnes -- endless runs in minor modes and keys that lack all warmth, reverie, or introspection.  Perhaps Mr. Mehldau ought to give Bill Evans a good listening to in order to learn something.

0060264306|5.0|\\"Once upon a time, sixty years ago, a little girl lived in the Big Woods of Wisconsin, in a little gray house made of logs.\\" So begins \\"Little House in the Big Woods,\\" by Laura Ingalls Wilder. The book tells the story of young Laura, a pioneer girl who lives with her Pa, Ma, sister Mary, baby sister Carrie, bulldog Jack, and Black Susan the cat.<br />This book is a richly detailed portrait of pioneer life. There isn't much of a plot; the book is basically a record of the day-to-day lives of this hardy pioneer family. The book goes into fascinating detail about the family's activities: butchering a hog, smoking meat, churning butter, making bullets, fiddling, harvesting maple syrup, and more. Also fascinating are the characters' encounters with the various wild animals of the big woods--some dangerous, some cute.<br />The characters are memorable. Ma is the quintessential pioneer woman: hard-working and resourceful. I really got the sense that she's the glue that holds the family together. Pa is a particularly colorful and lovable character: a hunter, trapper, and farmer who is also a musician and a master storyteller. Indeed, the oral tradition of storytelling is an important motif in the book.<br />It's fascinating to escape to a world without DVDs, movie theaters, CDs, cable television, the Internet, or the other modern things we take for granted. This book takes us back to such a world, and reveals it to be a colorful and fascinating place.

B000002GF8|5.0|The police attempted to record an album that had challenging intellectual content within and at the same time appealed to the masses.  This is a daunting challenge and they proved that they could do it with \\"Synchronicity.\\"  I like to think of this album as a bunch of pieces that when separated have nothing to do with each other but when they come together they all fit together and speak about eachother.  This is perhaps near what Carl Jung's synchronicity philosophy is about, although I am not sure.  Sting's lyrical work is easily his finest out of all the police albums and perhaps the finest of his career.  The lyrics in \\"King of Pain\\" speak volumes if you really try to understand them.  \\"Every Breath You take\\" can be looked at as a love song or as a song by an obsessive ex-lover.  Either way it is one of Sting's all time best, if not the best.  Stewart Copeland contributes his best song out of all his previous contributions.  Miss Gradenko is a great song about some teacher who is having problems in class.  This school is different because everyone seems to be forced to behave like un-emotional robots.  Although some people would not say that Andy Summers \\"mother\\" is not a contribution but a proverbial smudge on an otherwise immaculate floor.  I think Mother is a pretty disturbing song but it is also very original and it took me awhile but I eventually appreciated it.  It somehow fits well into the mix.  The album warms up with the first three songs but it really gets going with \\"Synchronicity II.\\"  The best four songs on the album are tracks 6, 7, 8, and 9.  \\"Wrapped around your finger\\" is as with most of the songs brilliant lyrically.  The great part about that song is that it is about a relationship that changes or actually it switches.  It is one of the most inspiring songs I have ever heard about a love relationship.  \\"Tea in the Sahara\\" can be described as beautiful and serene.  \\"Murder by numbers\\" is a perfect way to the end the album.  It is a smart commentary on modern society and it's indifference to violence.  It is also a criticism of the governments ability to wage war and kill masses of people.  This album is described as the police's best but I actually think that it is a tie between this one and \\"Ghost in the machine\\" as their best album.  So get both, and experience some of the best music that was ever recorded.
0345423496|5.0|I really enjoyed this book, but I must agree with those who said the previous books more. My only complaint is that I would have liked more.  Clarke could have carried on for a thousand pages about future technology and political changes without boring me.  He did a good job making me feel Poole's disorientation in discovering a new world.<br />It was nice that the book acknowledges that language would have changed.  The idea that English will become the universal language seems quite plausible to me, although one might have said the same thing about Japanese many years ago.  Anglish is a fitting name for the fictional language of the future-- obviously owing to influence from French and other languages.<br />I found the explanation of the monolith to be satisfying.  The only thing that disappointed me was the plan they used to resist the monolith-it's seemed a bit facile for something as powerful as the monolith.<br />Judging by the changes the world has seen in the last 1000 years and the rate of change since the industrial revolution, I believe the changes in the next 1000 years will go way beyond what is in this book.  Despite Clarke's insight, he can only fall short of creating a convincing future.  This book is a great story and a starting point for thinking about humanity's distant future.

B00000099Y|3.0|... I guess Tool is just one of those bands you love or hate; with a vengance. One would imagine that the band would be quite pleased to see such a passionate variance of opinion about their work. It means they're doing their job as artists. I, personally, am not a big fan of rock music in general. I think one of the reasons some of the reviewers were disappointed is because Tool is quite often mistakenly classified as \\"Heavy Metal\\". Before you buy this you should know that this is not Metallica, Sepultra, or Korn. If you haven't or can't imagine sitting through an entire performance of a symphony, then Tool is not for you. If you want to dance, sing along, or bang your head and \\"throw goats\\", Tool is not for you. If you enjoy LISTENING to creative, well-crafted, emotionally stirring modern music, you may want to give Tool a shot. But be warned! This CD is not without flaws and you may want to have your remote handy so you can skip to the good stuff.<BR>Here's what I didn't like:<BR><BR>1. FILLER with a capital \\"F\\". Other reviewers have commented on this as well and they were right on the money on at least this point. The only bit of filler I would've kept was the 56 second \\"Intermission\\". I don't know how many noticed, but it's the first 56 seconds of the following song played on a hokey little organ. It's pretty amusing. The fact that there are only about 8 actual songs on this is what prompted me to give it 3 1/2 stars.<BR><BR>2. Most of the songs do have the same structure. ... You'll hear that they both have the same loud-timechange-soft-loud-timechange-soft formula to them. So yes, they do have a formula, but at least it's a formula that works!<BR><BR>3. Hooker with a Penis. It just doesn't have the finesse and emotion of the other tracks, but I guess even the best bands are guilty of some rock star ego posturing...<BR><BR>What I liked:<BR>Stinkfist(beautiful!!!), Eulogy, H., Forty Six and 2, Jimmy, and Aenema(Fret for your figure and Fret for your latte and Fret for your hairpiece and Fret for your lawsuit and Fret for your prozac and Fret for your pilot and Fret for your contract and Fret for your car...)These songs (especially Stinkfist and Aenema) make you feel like a ragdoll on a rollercoaster one minute and an infant sleeping on a cloud the next. Nobobdy who REALLY enjoys music can possibly deny that Tool can most definitely play. These guy's instruments are not just extensions of their penises. Danny Carey plays like a musician, not just a drummer. He knows when to hit you head on and when to tease. He is one of the few rock drummers today that really know how to use a kit to its full advantage (also see Matt Cameron and Jimmy Chamberlin). Justin Chancellor's bass is smooth and articulate, the second half of what has got to be one of the tightest rhythm sections in music today. Adam Jones is no slouch, either. True, he is not the absolute best guitarist ever, but he has a fabulous understanding of melody and mood, probably due to his early training as a violinist. His ambient and creative use of guitars is a huge part of Tool's sound. Maynard James Keenan's vocals and lyrics are...well, lets just say that if Mr. Keenan would like to call me up and sing to me sometime (ala Tori Amos), I'd definitely make myself available. Like most rock singers, he's no Placido Domingo, but he does know how to evoke an emotion and get his point across (also see Thom Yorke). Tool is most definitely an excellent band and are quite worthy of the praise they receive. They make an obvious effort to create something personal and artistic. I don't lend much creedence to the whole \\"intelligent rock\\" thing. If I want to be taught or lectured at, I'll go get indoctrinated at some university somewhere. What I do want out of my music is catharsis, which is what I think Tool provides impeccably.
B000069HKH|5.0|Fabulous album which pays a great deal of respect to September 11th, 2001.  Only the Boss can pull off such a stunning album mostly about a very difficult topic.
B000000OAN|5.0|... and in 1992, I was only 7. The first Queen song I heard was, obviously, Bohemian Rhapsody. It was around the time when Wayne's World came out (one of my favorite movies ever), and Queen's popularity was in a resurgeance, even though Freddie Mercury, sadly, succumbed to AIDS on 11/24/91. But for X-Mas I got a copy of this album. Very diverse, unabashedly campy, in your face, hard rockin, \\"[rear]-kicking\\" and influential.<BR><br />Death On two Legs - If there's one thing Queen knew how to do perfectly, it was starting up an album. From the piano arpeggios, to Brian May's sinister guitar tones, this song is very heavy and very angry as well, an emotion Queen very rarely delved into. 5/5<BR><br />Lazing On A Sunday Afternoon - Filler to most people, but I just love it! Could be in a musical. 5/5 <BR><br />I'm In Love With My Car - Roger Taylor's high-pitched vocals, and the heaviness of this song create the perfect Anthem of Machismo, and how men love their cars. 5/5.<BR><br />You're My best Friend is a simple love song and one of the biggest hits of Queen's career. 5/5 <BR><br />'39: Brian May's McCartney-like crooning and pretty stupid lyrics. Usually one I skip over. The guitar harmonies are excellent though. 3/5 <BR><br />Sweet Lady is another rocker. May's guitar really roars toweards the end of this song. 5/5 <BR><br />Seaside Rendezvous - OK, I respect Queen's campy side, and since they had the balls to do it in such a machismo-orinete industry, but this is perhaps just a bit too far. 2/5 <BR><br />Prophet's Song - Haunting, beautiful, aggressive, and one hell of a middle section with Freddie's resonant and echoing accapella. My favorite Queen song... EVER! 5/5.<BR><br />Love of My Life - Dammit, this song is a tearjerker. 5/5<BR><br />Good Company - Pass. Brian May takes his McCartney-esque solo side way too far on this album. 2/5.<br />Bohemian Rhapsody - need I say anything? 5/5<BR><br />God Save The Queen - Another example on what a genius brian May is when it comes to orchestrating guitars (see \\"Procession\\" off of Queen 2). 5/5.<BR><br />Overall, it's a very strong record with a few lows, but many highs.
B000063COX|5.0|Here is the album that introduced the world to Iron Maiden. They were a new band. A different band. One that dared to enter a world that was peppered with punk rockers and play a completely different style of music. They would later grow into one of the most sucessful bands in history. But in this album, they are captured only as a new band struggling to compete with the other bad boys. None of them knew what was to come.<BR>The album kicks of with the ever popular (and catchy) Prowler, which is an absolute masterpiece in itself. The next song, Sanctuary, was not originally released with the album, but this first attempt still charted at # 4! Iron Maiden's first singer, Paul Di'anno and, of course, Steve Harris team up to create the third tune entitled Remember Tomorrow. It starts out quiet and serene, but bursts into a wild frenzy as only Iron Maiden can do. Track 4 is possibly one of Maiden's greatest songs called Running Free. It is an incredible song that displays all of Maiden's talent. The next song is the perfect, the awesome and amazingly astounding Phantom of the Opera. No words can describe the sheer power and flowing rhythm of this one. It starts out in a rather common way, but launches into a full and ecstatic whirlwind of music. Paul Di'anno is not needed for the next song because it is Transylvania, which happens to be instrumental. It focuses purely on the musical abilities of Maiden, which are demonstrated so well in this tune. Then comes a different side of Iron Maiden. A calm and quiet song named Strange World. Light taps on the cymbals and gentle fills on the drums make for a perfect background for the painstaking guitar work. Charlotte the Harlot has a touch of uniqueness, possibly because it was written by  Guitarist Dave Murray. It, like Porwler, is quite catchy and a smashing piece of work. Then comes the anthem of the band and the title track. Iron Maiden is so simple, yet it doesn't compromise the song at all. In fact, Iron Maiden is still one of my favorite tunes. Iron Maiden can't be fought. Iron Maiden can't be sought. You have to listen to it. Do no hesitate to buy the only album that includes Iron Maiden's first guitarist. Get the album that came before Bruce and Nicko, when Paul Di'anno had the microphone and Clive Burr controlled the beats.<BR>And just when you thought it couldn't get any better, guess what? It actually gets better!! If you have the capabilities to access the CD extra, you can view exclusive footage of Iron Maiden playing live at the Rainbow in London in 1981. The two clips are of Phantom of the Opera and Iron Maiden. The video from which they are taken is called Live at the Rainbow. It is very rare (I found a copy on eBay) but this CD gives you the unique opportunity to see Iron Maiden in one of their first concerts. It's to cool not to get!!
0783240503|5.0|What really sets this video apart from other stage productions is that it was obviously directed for a video audience. So many other stage productions (Riverdance, for example) are merely filmed during an actual performance, where the cameras have limited access, the sound is generally poor and the lighting designed for the theater audience rather than the home viewer. Not so with Joseph! This production is clearly directed specifically for the home viewer - it looks and sounds wonderful.<br />Donny Osmond is a likeable Joseph and Maria Friedman, a huge talent, is absolutely perfect as the Narrator.<br />The musical, a pop opera, is brilliantly concieved by Rice and Webber. The changes in musical styles to fit the various dramatic moods will bring a smile to your lips (especially the depiction of Pharoh - I won't spoil it if you haven't seen it yet. It's almost laugh out loud funny).<br />The sets, the production numbers, the lighting, the performances, are all top notch. The video is a &quot;must see&quot; for adults and kids alike.

B000002V0Q|4.0|As all decent, self-respecting metalheads know, \\"Countdown to Extinction\\" was Megadeth's hugely successful follow-up to the classic \\"Rust in Peace.\\"  The long, complex epics like \\"Hangar 18\\" and \\"Tornado of Souls\\" that characterized \\"Rust in Peace\\" were gone, replaced by shorter and more accessible songs that actually had decent chances at radio airplay.  However, more commercially palatable does not mean bad, and on \\"Countdown\\" Dave & crew conducted a clinic on how to bring metal to the masses without abandoning the genre's traditional fan base.<br />\\"Countdown\\" may have seen Megadeth toning down their progressive approach and writing songs with a more traditional verse-chorus-verse-chorus approach, but fortunately songs like \\"Architecture of Agression\\" and \\"Skin o' My Teeth\\" prove that Dave could write some memorable and catchy choruses.  Dave's vocals are also somewhat improved over previous albums, as his voice here has a somewhat \\"fuller\\" sound.  He can still be menacing when he wants to, and on \\"Sweating Bullets\\" he does perhaps his best sneering ever.  And of course, the musicianship is as tight as always.  As I said above, complex guitar showcases like those on \\"Rust in Peace\\" are missing, but there are still plenty of solid riffs and sharp solos.  David Ellefson's basslines are more evident than usual, giving the songs an extra crunch, and Nick Menza's drumming is nearly surgical in its precision.<br />The lyricism on \\"Countdown\\" is also worth noting.  On the band's previous albums Dave had shown an inclination toward social and political commentary, and \\"Countdown\\" sees the culmination of that trend.  A great deal of the songs here take on issues of importance, and it's done very intelligently.  \\"Skin O' My Teeth\\" discusses Dave's drug problem,\\" the hit \\"Symphony of Destruction\\" deals with power and corruption, and the title track is an angry tell-off to those who hunt endangered species for sport.  However, in my opinion the highlight of the album lyrically is the poignant \\"Foreclosure of a Dream,\\" which tells of the troubles of those left behind in American society and the quest for money.  For many of us it can be easy to forget about those who don't get to live the American dream, but songs like this can be a good reminder of what some go through.<br />Anyway, all in all this is an excellent album, and a worthy edition to the Megadeth pantheon.  I don't think it's their best, as I feel that honor is a toss-up between \\"Peace Sells...But Who's Buying,\\" \\"Rust In Peace,\\" and \\"Youthanasia.\\"  But its still important in its own way, especially for the intelligent and meaningful lyrics.  I hope I haven't gone on too long, but hey, I guess I had a lot to say.ally is the poignant \\"Foreclosure of a Dream,\\" which tells of the troubles of those left behind in American society and the quest for money.  For many of us it can be easy to forget about those who don't get to live the American dream, but songs like this can be a good reminder of what some go through. <br />Anyway, all in all this is an excellent album, and a worthy edition to the Megadeth pantheon.  I don't think it's their best, as I feel that honor is a toss-up between \\"Peace Sells...But Who's Buying,\\" \\"Rust In Peace,\\" and \\"Youthanasia.\\"  But its still important in its own way, especially for the intelligent and meaningful lyrics.  I hope I haven't gone on too long, but hey, I guess I had a lot to say.

B000001ESF|4.0|On their fourth studio album, Lee, Lifeson and Peart produced one of hard/progressive rock's all time classics.  They also found a logo with the Red Star and \\"naked guy\\" icons.<br />The album begins with some (slightly dated) sci-fi atmospherics that lead into the \\"2112 Overture\\", which introduces the instrumental themes that will appear during the piece. This song was credited \\"to the genius of Ayn Rand\\" and is largely based on her novel \\"Anthem\\", but here the character's discovery of the light bulb is replaced by a rediscovery of the guitar, a fitting image for a rock band.  The ending of this song is less upbeat than the novel, but the chilling \\"we have assumed control\\" at the end of the 2112 suite's \\"Finale\\" brings us to a resolution.  Top-notch instrumental performance from all three players, cosmic lyrics and song great singing by Geddy Lee make this a great piece.<br />\\"Side 2\\" presents five songs that break the album from \\"concept\\" mode.  \\"A Passage to Bangkok\\" features great travelogue imagery about \\"herbs and spices\\" and a nifty guitar lick.  \\"Twilight Zone\\" doesn't quite work for me instrumentally, but features little capsules from the famous TV series.  Rod Serling might have liked Rush.  \\"Lessons\\" is a surprise from Alex Lifeson, with some upbeat lyrics and nice heavy/soft dynamics.  I love the bassline in the \\"chorus\\" section. \\"Tears\\" is Geddy Lee's ballad contribution.  \\"Something for Nothing\\" is a great rocker, that builds from a nice guitar into into to some blazing metal and great vocal perfomance from Lee.<br />The packaging includes legible lyrics, with added story depth in the 2112 piece, wisely not included as spoken word like in \\"The Necromancer\\". 0743442539|5.0|Le Carre is an unusual writer in the spy/thriller genre in that he creates real people with real problems who also happen to be spies.  The story of Leamas, a spy for Britain during the cold war, is well discussed in the many reviews here.  So instead I will briefly focus on why this is such a great read.<br />The book works at several levels.  First, one could characterize this as a page-turner because of the subject matter of the cold war and intrigue.  But the story is also very complex and demands the reader pay attention to fully benefit.  LeCarre does not spell out everything for the reader and I found myself having to go back several times to understand what had transpired.  I actually rented the movie - a gloomy B&W portrayal with Richard Burton as Leamas - in order to sort out a few things from the book.  Secondly, one is never sure, even when finished, who the good guys are and vice versa.  This causes the reader to think and contemplate issues of right and wrong, and moral values.<br />At the end I was very sorry that the book ended but also looking forward to reading more of this authors work.  This was a great book!

It's not your cynical highly over-rated Robert Altman flick, or your totally stupid Shallow Hal waste if time.<br />But what is it than? It's a movie you see and feel with your heart -- go see it. 0316666343|4.0|Fourteen year-old Susie Salmon is raped and murdered on a snowy afternoon by a neighbor.  As she sits in heaven, or what she believes is heaven, Susie watches the affect that her murder has on her family and friends, and she tries to find some way to communicate with them, to let them know that she is all right.<br />Alice Sebold is a marvelously inventive writer who uses her poetry background well.  The language and the structure of this novel will delight readers who are accustomed to non-linear narratives.  Others might find it too frustrating.  The characters are well-written and believable, but there were some plot points that I thought hit a false note.<br />But what is most appealing is Sebold's reassurance, through Susie, that heaven does exist, that the dead watch the living and try to help, that being dead is just a different kind of living.
